Problem Overview

In this Problem, students consider long-term average. This is also called expected value which is studied in more depth in high school. If a basketball player with a 60% free-throw percentage goes to the line for a one-and-one situation throughout the season, what is his or her average for each one-and-one free throw situation? Students will have looked at mean average in 6th grade.

Emerging Mathematical Ideas

Expand the understanding of finding probabilities of compound events to determine long-term averages

Notice that:

  • To find long-term averages you begin with a model to represent all possible outcomes
  • The model of all possible outcomes will determine the likelihood each outcome will occur
  • To find the long-term average multiply each of the possible outcomes by the likelihood each outcome will occur and add all of those values. Then divide by the number of trials.

NWDYK

How is the long-term average of an event different from the probability of an outcome for the event?

Launch (Getting Started)

Connecting to Prior Knowledge

Review with students the concept of mean average. Relate this to looking at the average number of points for each one-and-one free throw situation. Introduce the vocabulary work long-term average.

Presenting the Challenge

Discuss how they will be computing Nishi's long-term average for 100 one-and-one free-throw situations.

Suggested question

  • In 100 one-and-one free throw situations, how many times could Nishi expect to get a score of 0? A score of 1? A score of 2? (Accept any thoughts students have at this point. 40 times for a score of 0; 24 times for a score of 1; 36 times for a score of 2.)
